Content: As of May 13, the CDC recommends that fully vaccinated individuals can resume normal activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing,  except in limited circumstances. To find a vaccine clinic near you, visit our website or call 1-800-985-6030.
Wearing a mask protects you and others from COVID-19. Wear a mask in situations when you cannot socially distance. Learn more about ADH’s recommendations for wearing masks here:

If you have been fully vaccinated – which means two weeks after your second Moderna or Pfizer dose, or two weeks after the single-dose Johnson ; Johnson vaccine – you can safely gather indoors with other fully vaccinated people without wearing a mask. Learn more in this graphic:
This St. Patrick’s Day, be sure to wear a mask when you are around others outside of your household, even if it’s not green.

If you have been fully vaccinated – which means two weeks after your second Moderna or Pfizer dose, or two weeks after the single-dose Johnson ; Johnson vaccine – you can gather indoors with other fully vaccinated people without wearing a mask. Learn more in this graphic:
As we begin to experience warmer weather, don’t forget your mask when heading outside. It’s one of the best ways to protect yourself and others from COVID-19.

Going out? Keep these items on hand when in public spaces: a mask, disinfecting wipes, and a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol, if possible. Learn more about everyday ways to slow the spread of :

You should still wear a mask, avoid close contact with others and follow other COVID-19 guidelines even if you have received both doses of the vaccine. For other answers to frequently asked questions about the COVID-19 vaccines, go to:

Make sure your face covering is doing the most to protect you and others from : Add an additional layer and help ensure a snug fit by wearing two face coverings. If you wear two face coverings, wear a cloth covering over a disposable mask:

Face coverings that fit loosely allow respiratory droplets to enter and leak out. Consider double masking for better protection against .  If you decide to wear two face coverings, wear a cloth face covering over a disposable mask:

When you wear a face covering, you protect people around you in case you are infected but do not know it. You can get better protection by wearing two masks (a cloth mask over a disposable mask), which improves the fit and adds layers:

Face coverings save lives – wear one and wear it correctly: snug against your face and covering both your nose and mouth. Be sure to use a face covering with two or three layers of material. You can also use a cloth face covering over a disposable mask:

The CDC recommends that anyone who is not vaccinated continue to wear a mask in public indoor settings and outdoors when they cannot maintain social distance.

Now is the time to get vaccinated if you haven’t. With more people not wearing masks going forward and COVID-19 and its more infectious variants spreading, there is a real risk that unvaccinated people can get it. Please be responsible and wear a mask until you get vaccinated.
🏢 Public facing businesses should post signage reminding guests to social distance and wear a face covering if they are not fully vaccinated.
🏢 Businesses may choose to continue to require that their customers wear masks and we will continue to have recommendations for how businesses can best protect their employees and customers.
➡️ People who are NOT vaccinated should wear a mask and maintain distance in all indoor public settings and in outdoor settings where 6 feet of social distance is not possible.

Effective immediately, we are lifting all mandatory capacity and gathering limits and social distancing requirements and most mandatory mask requirements. Everyone, including fully vaccinated people will still be required to wear a mask in certain settings.

People who are not vaccinated should wear a mask and maintain distance in all indoor public settings and outdoor settings when they cannot maintain 6 feet of distance. Businesses may choose to continue to require that customers wear masks.

Everyone, including people who are fully vaccinated, will still be required to wear masks on public transportation, in health care settings like hospitals, doctor’s offices and nursing homes, and congregate settings like correctional facilities and homeless shelters.

Following new CDC guidance, Governor Cooper has lifted gathering limits and social distancing requirements in all settings and the indoor mask mandate for most settings. Everyone, including people who are fully vaccinated, will still be required to wear masks in certain settings.

➡ Everyone still needs to wear a mask when they are in indoor public settings. That’s where our second goal comes in. Once at least 2/3 of North Carolina adults have at least one shot and if our trends are stable...
That's our first goal, and it’s a big step to bringing summer back to North Carolina. What won’t change on June 1 is the requirement for people to wear masks indoors in public settings.

➡ The CDC said if you’re fully vaccinated, you’re outdoors and not in a big crowd, you no longer need to wear a mask. That’s great news for almost 40% of North Carolina adults who are already fully vaccinated!

The risk of COVID-19 transmission is lower when you wear a mask properly and keep at least 6 feet of distance from others. Together we can slow the spread of the virus and keep our family and neighbors safe.

: AG Yost spoke to kickoff the  for . We thank the men ; women who wear the badge that protect our communities and we must honor and pay respect to the officers who have paid the ultimate sacrifice.

The Ohio Peace Officers' Memorial Ceremony honored the officers who have given their lives in the line of duty. We share our deepest gratitude for those who wear the badge, past ; present, for their unwavering dedication ; selflessness to protecting Ohio.

However, the men ; women who wear a badge did not have the option of working from home, social distancing, or even guaranteeing that those they interact with wear a mask, but they still worked to protect their communities every day.

- Wash your hands before putting on your mask.

- Make sure you can breathe easily.

1/3 Protect yourself when shopping/running errands: 
- Stay at least 6 feet away from others
- Cover your nose ; mouth with a mask
- Go during hours when fewer people will be running errands
- If you are at higher risk for severe illness, find out if stores have special hours

When wearing a cloth face covering, where social distancing measures are difficult to maintain: 
- Make sure it fits snugly and covers your nose and mouth. 
- Change them frequently. 
- Wash them when they are soiled or wet. 
- Avoid touching your cloth covering or face.
when in public to help slow the spread of COVID-19. Masks should fully cover your nose and mouth. If you’re not wearing your mask properly,  particles can spread.
Make sure your mask covers your nose AND your mouth and that it fits snug to your face. If you are double masking, make sure to wear a disposable mask underneath your cloth mask.
Wearing a mask protects you and everyone around you. Make sure the mask fits snug to your face and covers your mouth and your nose.
